is a |-separated list of option names. It should be listed in shortest-to-longest order, e.g. h|help. may contain a specifier following one of the |-separated entries, and a value separator list following the specifier.

The property is initialized based on whether a = or : follows one of the aliases within . = specifies a value, while : specifies an value. If neither = nor : is not specified, then is used. The value specifier may be used anywhere within , so n|name=, n=|name and n=|name= are equivalent, but you cannot mix types; n:|name= is invalid.

A default handler may be specified by using <> as the option name. The default handler is invoked for any unhandled argument within ; consequently, if a default handler is provided then
will return an empty .

The default handler may either be provided as a stand-alone , in which case it may not specify a other than . Alternatively, it may be an alias, in which case the must accept an or value, and must be 1.

Multiple values may be bundled together, such as -opt key=value. The value separator list specifies which characters can be used to split the value argument to generate separate values. The value separator list is available when is greater than 1, and and an was specified. The value separator list follows the = or : and is one of the following:

term.para: A sequence of character enclosed by { and }. Multiple such sequences may be specified by listing the {...} sequence multiple times.

The sequence {} requires that each value be a different argument, and no argument splitting will be performed. This sequence has no effect if other separators are also listed (as separate arguments are always permitted for
values).

item.term: Any literal character other than { and }.

remarks.para: If the separator list is not provided, then =: is the default separator list.

For example, the prototype "A:+-*/" would permit any of `+', `-', `*', or `/' to be used to split an argument into values, so -A:5/2 would generate the sequence of values 5 and 2 for the option -A. Furthermore, the prototype "A={-->}{=>}" would permit either the string --> or the string => to be used, so -A A->B C woud parse A->B as one value and C as the other value, while -A A-->B C would parse A as one value and B as the other value while C would be unhandled (unless the option required 3 values, in which case C would be the 3rd value).
